Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Tracking Long-Term Glacial-Interglacial Wind Pattern Variability in Central Asia Using Geochemical Analysis of Aerosol Derived Detritus
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a project to reconstruct the position of the winds, the patterns of the circulation and the source regions for the dust in central and eastern Asia during the Quaternary, the last 2.5 million years. The researchers will employ a novel technique of "fingerprinting" the chemical composition of the dust found in wind-derived sediments as well as in a variety of potential upstream source regions. The chemical characterization will be made using laser ablation mass spectrometry and the measurements will include U/Pb dating, trace metal measurements, and Hf (hafnium) isotope variability to determine source regions for the dust. The approach - using laser ablation mass spectrometry on individual zircon grains - is likely to provide unprecedented chemical information about the minerals and the rapid rate of sample analysis will produce strong a strong statistical basis for evaluating changes in grain chemistry and source region.

The broader impacts include: 1) application of a novel, new approach for characterizing the chemistry of the dust grains; 2) support for graduate students and undergraduates at two universities to participate in the research; 3) support for a new researcher embarking on an academic career; and 4) a strong element of international collaboration between the Institute of Tibetan Research in China and two universities in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth’s climate systems have change profoundly over the past 8.0 million years culminating in the amplification of colder temperature periods (glacials) and warmer temperature periods (interglacials) starting around 2.6 million years ago. Our ability to quantify major differences in atmospheric circulation patterns during marked changes in past climates strongly influences our capacity to accurately forecast future patterns. Wind is the most prominent driver on ocean circulation, and distributes atmospheric thermal energy and moisture around the Earth.

Wind-transported rock dust archived in the geologic record provides a means for reconstructing past wind patterns. Determining the provenance of the mineral components which compose these dust archives have enabled us to better understand wind patterns over Asia and the North Pacific Ocean during the past 42 million years with an emphasis on the changing wind patterns between glacial and interglacial periods over the past 2.6 million years. This NSF project improved our ability to efficiently, accurately, and precisely determine the provenance of mineral components within the dust through age dating of detrital zircon minerals and identifying the sources of those minerals. First order wind patterns were reconstructed by determining the timing and pathways that the mineral dusts took to arrive at their respective depositional areas.

 The mineral dating of samples and geomorphic mapping of one of the largest and most complete archives of wind-transported dust in Asia, the Chinese Loess Plateau, and its source areas have provided empirical evidence elucidating atmospheric circulation patterns across broad time-scales. The age dating provenance approach showed that >50% of the minerals dated in glacial period age deposits can be attributed to sources to the west and southwest of the Loess Plateau. This observation supports a scenario in which the mean positions of the Northern Hemisphere westerly jet streams shift equatorward during glacial periods. Implicit in this observation is a corollary poleward shift in westerly jet streams with continued warming of the Earth’s atmosphere. In addition, dating of minerals within the 2.6 million year old section of loess showed that a large portion of this section was sourced from internal recycling of sediment. This observation along with geomorphic mapping demonstrated that the Chinese Loess Plateau has been eroded by the wind, and in addition to being a sink for atmospheric dust over the past 2.6 million years, it has also been a source of dust.

 In order to identify long-term trends in the aridification of central Asia this project investigated wind-transported dust deposits older than 2.6 million years. The dating approach applied to older deposits shows a resilience of the atmospheric circulation over Asia that can be traced to at least 42 million years ago. These long standing atmospheric conditions favor the prominence of arid conditions in much of central Asia from 42 million years ago through the present. This shows that major changes in the local topography, inland water bodies, and global climate had little influence over the generally arid conditions that have prevailed in central Asia over the past 42 million years. The provenance of wind-transported dust indicates that near surface winds and mid-levels winds would be indistinguishable from modern observations.

 

Just prior to the beginning of glacial-interglacial cycles at 2.6 million years ago rates at which dust was accumulating in the North Pacific Ocean and at the Chinese Loess Plateau covary. In addition, the Asian sources of this dust also change during this time period. Age dating of zircon minerals showed that increases in the rates at which dust accumulated at the Chinese Loess Plateau are associated with greater contributions from low elevation areas in central-east Asia. This resulted from higher rates of river incision as the East Asian Monsoon intensified and generated more unconsolidated sediment within central-east Asian that could be carried by the wind under the generally arid conditions.

As for broader impacts, this project: 1) supported two postdoctoral researchers that trained in cross-disciplinary research (i.e., geology and climatology); 2) engaged one undergraduate student in the mineral dating process and database management as a paid research assistant; and 3) strengthened international collaboration between U.S. institutions and the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Project results were presented at nine conferences, five invited colloquium talks, and in six peer reviewed publications (four published, two in review).
